results.title: Weed
results.creator_credit: Concept Films, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Brian Kellman
results.brief_description: Traces the use of marijuana throughout history. Compares past and present attitudes towards it use. Discusses known physiological and psychological effects, plans for future research into still unanswered questions about these effects, and the social and legal implications of possession.

results.title: Wednesdays [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Jeremy Stanford
results.brief_description: Shelly (Josephine Byrnes) awakens one Wednesday morning and slowly descends down the stairs in her pajamas. As the morning progresses the viewer learns of love found, lost, jealousy, suspicion and a murder as she retraces the steps of how she discovered her partner, John’s (Greg Stone) infidelity - or does she?

results.title: Wednesday in April
results.brief_description: In image and sound, the film describes an average day as it is lived across the varied scene of the continent of America. Cowboy, farmer or urban worker, every citizen is free to weave his own unique pattern into the infinite, multi-colored American tapestry. Narrated by Lee Marvin.

results.title: Wedlock: a satirical fantasy
results.creator_credit: Ed Spiegel and Louis Clyde Stoumen
results.brief_description: A fantasy which satirises the obscure symbolism of some “experimental” films. Skilled montage of quite disconnected shots adds up to excitement, and often to irony. However, the theme of disenchantment in marriage is treated only lightly, and is soon lost in a desire to exploit the effects of seeping, oozing liquids, intercut with portraits of problem people.

results.title: Wedgwood
results.creator_credit: World Wide, Clifford Parris and Ray Townsend
results.brief_description: An insight into the world of Wedgwood - one of the most celebrated pottery manufacturers in the world. Bernard Price talks about the extraordinary man Joshua I, who founded the company in 1759, and then discusses Wedgwood designs, both antique and modern, with a number of people both inside and outside the Wedgwood organisation.

results.title: Wedding in Galilee = Noce en Galilee [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Marisa Films, LPA, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Michel Khleifi
results.brief_description: Abu Adel, the Mukhtar of a Palestinian village is given permission to hold a traditional wedding for his son on the condition that the Israeli military governor and his staff be guests of honor at the ceremony. Agreeing to the governor’s condition immediately created division and anger amongst his family, and the village community, resulting in a conspiracy by some of the younger men to sabotage the wedding and kill the governor and his soldiers. Conflict between families, the underlying tension between the Israelis and the wedding guests, failure of the groom to consummate his marriage, and the hatred which the groom has for his father, are just some of the many threads which weave this intriguing story together to provide an insight into the culture, contradictions and hostilities which exist in occupied Palestine. “Wedding in Galilee” was the first feature film made in Palestine by a Palestinian director, Michel Khleifi (Forbidden marriages in the Holy Land, 1995), who believes that “culture is meant to be controversial”. This international multi-award winning film is controversial in more ways than one with its blend of politics and culture, and sensuality and sexuality. Although a slow-moving, lyrical film, there is however, an underlying intensity, an expectation that disaster is imminent. Sadly and quite ironically, the Intifada began only six months after the film was shot. Cast includes Makram Khouri, Youssef Abou Wardeh, Jouliano Mer Khamis, Buchra Karaman, Anna Achdian, Nazih Akleh, Sonia Amar. (Awards: Cannes; San Sebastian; Belgium; Tunisia) In Arabic and Hebrew with English subtitles.

results.title: Wedding at York
results.brief_description: The wedding of HRH the Duke of Kent and Miss Katherine Worsley at York Minster. As the bride leavers her home, members of the Royal Family assemble at the great cathedral. The arrival of Her Majesty the Queen with Prince Philip and Prince Charles is followed by the ceremony at which Dr Ramsey, then Archbishop of York, officiated. The wedding over, the bride and her husband leave the cathedral to the cheers of waiting crowds.

results.title: Wedding
results.brief_description:
An interactive CD-ROM produced as part of Victorian College of the Arts Interactive Media degree. ‘Wedding’ allows an interactive exploration of different characters at a wedding. A wide range of permuations are generated as the user selects characters to interact with each other; triggering recorded conversations and short movie pieces.

“Wedding explores behaviours and expectations that seem to be exclusively associated with weddings. Not only from the bride, but from her friends and family as well - it seemed that weddings stil retain much of their symbolic power in people’s imagination. ‘Wedding’ uses interactivity to give the user the chance to explore a non-linear situationwith characters that they choose and identify with or are interested in”.

results.title: Weaving linen
results.brief_description: A general account of modern factory methods of weaving linen. The following processes are illustrated: preparing the weft yarn for the shuttle; preparing the warp; threading the heddles; weaving the linen; and the finish processes including pre-shrinking, scalding, bleaching and dyeing, calendering and folding. An animated diagram is used to explain how the loom works.

An animated diagram is used to explain how the loom works.

results.title: Weaving
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: Illustrates how weaving is a practical craft, vital to the survival of the Pushtu tribe. Shows how the Pushtu women work on old, crude portable wooden looms. This program has no dialogue but a soundtrack.
